All generation and load within the area defined by the terminals on the border are considered in the area interchange control. Note that any number of overlapping control area specifications can be superimposed on the physical model. The following general principles apply to ControlArea:
1.  The control area orientation for net interchange is positive for an import, negative for an export.
2.  The control area net interchange is determined by summing flows in Terminals. The Terminals are identified by creating a set of TieFlow objects associated with a ControlArea object. Each TieFlow object identifies one Terminal.
3.  In a single network model, a tie between two control areas must be modelled in both control area specifications, such that the two representations of the tie flow sum to zero.
4.  The normal orientation of Terminal flow is positive for flow into the conducting equipment that owns the Terminal. (i.e. flow from a bus into a device is positive.) However, the orientation of each flow in the control area specification must align with the control area convention, i.e. import is positive. If the orientation of the Terminal flow referenced by a TieFlow is positive into the control area, then this is confirmed by setting TieFlow.positiveFlowIn flag TRUE. If not, the orientation must be reversed by setting the TieFlow.positiveFlowIn flag FALSE.

ControlArea.OutageCoordinationRegion.description: The outage coordination region that has this control area.

ControlArea.PartOf.description: The control area that is part of this control area.

ControlArea.SystemOperator.description: The system operator that operates this control area.

CoordinatedCapacityCalculator.description: A role that coordinates and executes the task of calculating transmission capacity.

CurrentControlFunction.description: Current control function is a function block that calculates the operating point of the controlled equipment  to achieve the target current.

CurrentDroopControlFunction.description: Current droop control function is a function block that calculates the operating point of the controlled equipment to achieve the target current.

CurrentDroopControlFunction.droopCapacit.description: Droop in capacitive region. The unit is V/A.

CurrentDroopControlFunction.droopInducti.description: Droop in inductive region. The unit is V/A.

CurrentFlow.description: Electrical current with sign convention: positive flow is out of the conducting equipment into the connectivity node. Can be both AC and DC.

CurrentDroopOverride.description:
Current droop override uses the following logic:
- When the current exceeds a threshold the device executes the following transitions: 1) When injecting an inductive voltage or in monitoring mode the device tends to inject a voltage proportional to the difference between the line current and the aforementioned threshold. 2) When injecting a capacitive voltage the device transitions to monitoring mode. 
- If the aforementioned proportional voltage is lower than the initial one, the voltage injection remains unchanged. 
Current droop override is not applied when the device operates in currentDroop mode.

CurrentDroopOverride.SSSCController.description: The SSSC controller to which this CurrentDroopOverride applies to.

CurrentDroopOverride.droopCapacitive.description: Droop in capacitive region. The unit is V/A.

CurrentDroopOverride.droopInductive.description: Droop in inductive region. The unit is V/A.

CurrentDroopOverride.mRID.description:
Master resource identifier issued by a model authority. The mRID is unique within an exchange context. Global uniqueness is easily achieved by using a UUID, as specified in RFC 4122, for the mRID. The use of UUID is strongly recommended.
For CIMXML data files in RDF syntax conforming to IEC 61970-552, the mRID is mapped to rdf:ID or rdf:about attributes that identify CIM object elements.

CurveData.description: Multi-purpose data points for defining a curve.  The use of this generic class is discouraged if a more specific class can be used to specify the X and Y axis values along with their specific data types.

CurveData.Curve.description: The curve of  this curve data point.

CurveData.xvalue.description: The data value of the X-axis variable,  depending on the X-axis units.

CurveData.y1value.description: The data value of the  first Y-axis variable, depending on the Y-axis units.

CurveData.y2value.description: The data value of the second Y-axis variable (if present), depending on the Y-axis units.

DCBiPole.description: DC system bipole (IEC 60633), which is part of an DC system consisting of two independently operable DC system poles, which during normal operation, exhibit opposite direct voltage polarities with respect to earth.

DCBiPole.BipolarDCSystem.description: Bipolar DC system that has this DC bipole.

DCBreaker.description: A breaker within a DC system.

DCConductingEquipment.ratedCurrent.description:
The maximum continuous current carrying capacity in amps governed by the device material and construction.
The attribute shall be a positive value.

DCBusbar.description: A busbar within a DC system.

DCBypassSwitch.description: By-pass switch (IEC 60633) is a high-speed DC switch connected across each converter valve group in DC schemes using more than one independent converter per pole, designed to close rapidly to bypass a converter group that is being taken out of service and commutate the current back into a valve group that is being taken back in service. A by-pass switch may also be used for prolonged shunting of the bridge(s).

DCChopper.description: Low resistance equipment used in the internal DC circuit to balance voltages. It has typically positive and negative pole terminals and a ground.

DCConverterParallelingSwitch.description: Converter paralleling switch (IEC 60633) is a high-speed DC switch connected in series with each converter at the DC terminal in DC schemes where two or more converters are connected in parallel onto a common pole conductor, designed to allow additional converter(s) to be connected in parallel or disconnected without affecting the load current in the other converter.

DCConverterUnit.description: Indivisible operative unit comprising all equipment between the point of common coupling on the AC side and the point of common coupling – DC side, essentially one or more converters, together with one or more converter transformers, converter control equipment, essential protective and switching devices and auxiliaries, if any, used for conversion.

DCConverterUnit.Substation.description: The containing substation of the DC converter unit.

DCConverterUnit.ACPointOfCommonCoupling.description: AC point of common coupling for this DC converter unit.

DCConverterUnit.DCPointOfCommonCoupling.description: DCNode that is the point of common coupling at DC side of this DCConverterUnit.

DCConverterUnit.DCPole.description: The DC pole that has this DC converter unit.

DCConverterUnit.DCSubstation.description: DC substation that has one or more DC converter units.

DCCurrentControlFunction.description: DC current control function is a function block that calculates the operating point of the controlled equipment  to achieve the target current.

PU.description: Per Unit - a positive or negative value referred to a defined base. Values typically range from -10 to +10.

DCCurrentControlFunction.droop.description: Droop constant. The pu value is obtained as D [kV/MW] x Sb / Ubdc. The attribute shall be a positive value.

DCCurrentControlFunction.droopCompensati.description: Compensation constant. Used to compensate for voltage drop when controlling voltage at a distant bus. The attribute shall be a positive value.

DCDisconnector.description: A disconnector within a DC system.

DCEarthReturnTransferSwitch.description: Earth return transfer switch (IEC 60633) DC commutation switch used to transfer DC current from a metallic return path to an earth return path. In some applications, this function is performed by a by-pass switch. Although the term "earth return transfer breaker" has been widely used in the industry for many years, it is misleading since such switches have no ability to interrupt fault current.

DCGround.description: A ground within a DC system.

DCHarmonicFilter.description: DC harmonic filter (IEC 60633) is a filter which, in conjunction with the DC reactor(s) and with the DC surge capacitor(s), if any, serves the primary function of reducing (current or voltage) ripple on the DC transmission line and/or earth electrode line.

DCLine.description: Overhead lines and/or cables connecting two or more HVDC substations.

DCLine.DCPole.description: The DC pole that has this DC line.

DCLineParallelingSwitch.description: Line paralleling switch (IEC 60633) DC commutation switch placed in series with one or more high-voltage pole conductors, allowing two or more lines to be connected in parallel or to revert to single-line operation while conducting load current.

DCLineSegment.description: A wire or combination of wires not insulated from one another, with consistent electrical characteristics, used to carry direct current between points in the DC region of the power system.

DCMetalicReturnSwitch.description: Metallic return transfer switch (IEC 60633) is a DC commutation switch used to transfer DC current from an earth return path to a metallic return path. Although the term "metallic return transfer breaker" has been widely used in the industry for many years, it is misleading since such switches have no ability to interrupt fault current.

DCNeutralBusGroundingSwitch.description: Neutral bus grounding switch (IEC 60633) or a neutral bus earthing switch is a DC commutation switch connected from the neutral bus to the station earth mat on a bipolar DC scheme, designed to provide a temporary earth connection in the event of an open circuit fault on the electrode line until the imbalance of current between the two poles can be reduced to a safe minimum level or the electrode line connection can be restored.

DCNeutralBusSwitch.description: Neutral bus switch (IEC 60633) is a DC commutation switch connected in series with the neutral bus on a bipolar DC scheme, designed to commutate current out of the pole conductor or neutral bus and into the electrode line or dedicated metallic return conductor or earth in response to a fault in a converter or neutral bus.

DCNode.description: DC nodes are points where terminals of DC conducting equipment are connected together with zero impedance.

DCPointOfCommonCoupling.description: Point of interconnection of the DC converter station to the DC transmission line (IEC 60633).

DCPointOfCommonCoupling.DCNode.description: The DCNode that is a point of common coupling DC.

DCPole.description: The direct current (DC) system pole (IEC 60633) is part of a DC system consisting of all the equipment in the DC substations and the interconnecting transmission lines, if any, which during normal operation exhibit a common direct voltage polarity with respect to earth.

DCPole.AsymmetricMonopolarDCSystem.description: Asymmetric monopolar DC system that has this DC pole.

DCPole.DCBiPole.description: DC system bipole that has two independently operatable DC system poles.

DCPole.DCTieCorridor.description: The DCTieCorridor that has this DC pole.

DCPole.normalParticipationFactor.description:
Normal participation factor describing the entity part of the active power provided by a collection of entities (e.g. an active power forecast to a collection of entities is divided to each of the member entity according to the participation factor). Must be a positive value.
In the case of a sharing strategy, the distribution is following entities value (V) equals aggregated value (T) divided by sum of participation factors (PF), i.e. V=T/sum(PF). 
In the case of priority strategy, the item with the lowest number gets allocated energy first.

DCSeriesDevice.description: A series device within the DC system, typically a reactor used for filtering or smoothing.  Needed for transient and short circuit studies.

DCShunt.description: A shunt device within the DC system, typically used for filtering.  Needed for transient and short circuit studies.

DCSmoothingReactor.description: Reactor (IEC 60633) connected in series with a converter unit or converter units on the DC side for the primary purpose of smoothing the direct current and reducing current transients.

DCSmoothingReactorArrester.description: Arrester (IEC 60633) connected between the terminals of a smoothing reactor.

DCSubstation.description: DC substation or DC converter station (IEC 60633) is part of an DC system which consists of one or more converter units installed in a single location together with buildings, reactors, filters, reactive power supply, control, monitoring, protective, measuring and auxiliary equipment. A DC substation forming part of an DC transmission system may be referred to as an DC transmission substation.

DCSubstation.Substation.description: Substation that contains this DC susbstation.

DCSubstation.isTapping.description: DC tapping substation (IEC 60633) is a DC substation, mainly used for inversion, with a rating which is a small fraction of that of the rectifier(s) in the system.

DCSubstationBipole.description: Part of a bipolar DC system (IEC 60633) contained within a DC substation.

DCSubstationBipole.DCSubstation.description: DC substation that contains this DC substation bipole part.

DCSubstationPole.description: Part of an DC system pole (IEC 60633) which is contained within a DC substation.

DCSubstationPole.DCSubstation.description: DC substation that contains this DC substation pole part.

DCSwitch.description: A switch within the DC system.

DCTieCorridor.description: A collection of one or more direct current poles that connect two different control areas.

DCTieCorridor.SchedulingArea.description: The scheduling area that has this DC tie corridor.

RampingPrincipleKind.continuous.description: Continuous ramping principle is applied between two scheduled time point. For instance, from 10 MW to 70 MW over one hour the change is 1 MW/min.

RampingPrincipleKind.fifteenMinutes.description: Fifteen minutes ramping principle. Ramping starts 15 minutes before the schedule time point and ends 15 minutes after. For instance, if the schedule time point is 19:30h it starts at 19:15h and ends at 19:45h.

RampingPrincipleKind.fiveMinutes.description: Five minutes ramping principle. Ramping starts five minutes before the schedule time point and ends five minutes after. For instance, if the schedule time point is 19:30h it starts at 19:25h and ends at 19:35h.

RampingPrincipleKind.maxContinuous.description: Maximum continuous ramping principle. The schedule is kept as long as possible and the maximum ramping rate is used to get from one point to another, symmetrically around the schedule time points. For example, there is 40 MW change in the schedule the maximum ramp rate is 20 MW/min the ramping starts 1 min before (e.g. 19:29h) and finishes 1 min after (e.g. 19:31h).

RampingPrincipleKind.tenMinutes.description: Ten minutes ramping principle. Ramping starts 10 minutes before the schedule time point and ends 10 minutes after. For instance, if the schedule time point is 19:30h it starts at 19:20h and ends at 19:40h.

DCTieCorridor.rampingKind.description: Ramping principle is used to define a transition from one scheduled value to next one.

DCVoltageControlFunction.description: DC voltage control function is a function block that calculate the operating point of the controlled equipment to achieve the target voltage.

DirectCurrentBipoleController.description: DC system bipole control that is the control system of a bipole in accordance with IEC 60633.

DirectCurrentBipoleController.DirectCurr.description: Direct current master controller which has direct current bipole controllers.

DirectCurrentCircuit.description: A direct current circuit is a circuit consists of direct current equipment.

Circuit.positiveFlowIn.description: True, if the positive value on the terminal shall be considered flow into the circuit. False, if the positive value on the terminal shall be considered flow out of the circuit.

DirectCurrentMasterController.description:
Direct current system control is a control system which governs the operation of an entire DC system consisting of more than one DC substation and performs those functions of controlling, monitoring and protection which require information from more than one substation. This can also be a multiterminal control which is a DC system control for more that two DC substations or a DC master control, which is a general concept for control coordination of a DC system. The DC master control may be implemented at the bipole and/or pole level as defined in IEC 60633. 
The DC system control/multiterminal control/master control is part of the hierarchical structure of an HVDC control system that has an integrated AC/DC system control as the highest level of control which governs the integrated operation of AC and DC systems of a power system. This control system is under the responsibility of the system operator.

DirectCurrentMasterController.DCTieCorri.description: DCTieCorridor controlled by this direct current master controller.

DirectCurrentPoleController.description: DC system pole control, which is the control system of a pole in accordance with IEC 60633.

DirectCurrentPoleController.DCPole.description: DC pole that is controlled by a DC pole controller.

DirectCurrentPoleController.DirectCurren.description: DC bipole controller that controls this DC pole controller.
DC master controller that has a DC pole controller.

DirectCurrentSubstationBipoleController.description: Control system of a substation bipole (IEC 60633).

DirectCurrentSubstationBipoleController..description: DC substation bipole that is controlled by a DC substation bipole controller.

DirectCurrentSubstationController.Multit.description: Multiterminal control that controls more than two DC substation controllers.

DirectCurrentSubstationPoleController.description: Control system of a substation pole (IEC 60633).

DirectCurrentSubstationPoleController.DC.description: DC substation pole that is controlled by a DC substation pole controller.

DirectCurrentSystemOperator.description: System operator of the direct current pole. There are typically one or two system operators that are operating either the control area at one side or the control areas at both sides of the direct current pole. In some cases it is operated by an operator from the connected control areas.

DistributionSystemOperator.description: A system operator that is responsible for operating of energy distribution network from transmission level down to low voltage levels including the connection to household.

DurationOverloadLimitCurve.description:
A curve or functional relationship between
- the overload duration independent variable (X-axis), and 
- temporary overloading (TATL) limiting dependent (Y-axis) variables.

EdgeControlArea.description: An EdgeControlArea representing the local, site-level (edge) operational domain that coordinates one or more Installations and their connections. It is typically operated by an edge operator (e.g., a person/company operating a campus, mall, microgrid, or prosumer cluster) and supports local monitoring, control, scheduling, and limits—both islanded and grid-connected.

EdgeSchedulingArea.description:
An EdgeSchedulingArea is a electrical area that is part of a SubSchedulingArea with one or more Installations connected.
It serves as the smallest energy level scheduling, forecasting and aggregated measurement used for coordinating energy production, consumption, and storage across its constituent connections.
An EdgeSchedulingArea may represent physical locations with multiple grid connection, such as a shopping mall, university campus, industrial facility, or private microgrid that are normally connected to the grid.

SchedulingArea.BiddingZone.description: The bidding zone related to this scheduling area.

SchedulingArea.ControlArea.description: The control area for this scheduling area.

SchedulingArea.EnergyCoordinationRegion.description: The energy coordination region that has this scheduling area.

SchedulingArea.LoadFrequencyControlArea.description: The load frequency control area which has this scheduling area.

SchedulingArea.PartOf.description: The scheduling area is part of this scheduling area.

SchedulingArea.PowerCapacity.description: Power capacity of this shaduling area.

SchedulingArea.SynchronousArea.description: The synchronous are that has this scheduling area.

SchedulingArea.SystemOperator.description: The system operator for this scheduling area.

SchedulingArea.isIslandingEnabled.description: Identifies if the area can operate in island operation. If true, the area is enabled (capable) of operating as an electrical island. If false, the area does not have the capability or it is not enabled to operate as an electrical island.

SchedulingArea.isMeteringGridArea.description: Identifies if the area is settlement metered for all import and export to the area. If true, the area is metered area. If false, it is not.

SchedulingArea.normalParticipationFactor.description:
Normal participation factor describing the entity part of the active power provided by a collection of entities (e.g. an active power forecast to a collection of entities is divided to each of the member entity according to the participation factor). Must be a positive value.
In the case of a sharing strategy, the distribution is following entities value (V) equals aggregated value (T) divided by sum of participation factors (PF), i.e. V=T/sum(PF). 
In the case of priority strategy, the item with the lowest number gets allocated energy first.

ElectricalChargingUnit.description: A unit that supplies electrical power for charging electrical non-stationary entities, e.g. electrical vehicle, trucks, buses, ferries, boats and airplanes. The characteristic is that the energy consumption is highly schedule dependent.

EnergyAlignmentCoordinator.description: A role that is responsible for alignment of forecast and schedule energy to a given energy coordination region.

EnergyBlockComponent.description: Energy block component where the energy group is distributed according to the energy block order of each energy component in an energy group.

EnergyComponent.EnergyConsumer.description: The energy consumer that relates to this energy component.

EnergyComponent.EnergyGroup.description: The energy group that has this energy component.

EnergyComponent.GeneratingUnit.description: The generating unit that is part of this energy component.

EnergyComponent.HydroPump.description: The hydro pump that relates to this energy component.

EnergyComponent.PowerElectronicsUnit.description: The power electronics unit that relates to this energy component.

EnergyBlockOrder.description: The energy block order is a block (an amount) of energy that forms the sequence of orders that are going to be distributed to an energy block component.

EnergyBlockOrder.EnergyBlockComponent.description: The energy block component that has this energy block order.

EnergyBlockOrder.normalSequence.description:
Normal sequence represents the local order of the power block order.

The sequence order for a given block dispatch instruction. The sequence number need to be unique for a given block dispatch instruction, e.g. two order in the same instruction cannot have the same sequence.

Duration.description: Duration as "PnYnMnDTnHnMnS" which conforms to ISO 8601, where nY expresses a number of years, nM a number of months, nD a number of days. The letter T separates the date expression from the time expression and, after it, nH identifies a number of hours, nM a number of minutes and nS a number of seconds. The number of seconds could be expressed as a decimal number, but all other numbers are integers.

EnergyConsumer.description:
Generic user of energy - a  point of consumption on the power system model.
EnergyConsumer.pfixed, .qfixed, .pfixedPct and .qfixedPct have meaning only if there is no LoadResponseCharacteristic associated with EnergyConsumer or if LoadResponseCharacteristic.exponentModel is set to False.

EnergyConsumer.maxEconomicP.description: Maximum high economic active power limit, that should not exceed the maximum operating active power limit.

EnergyConsumer.minEconomicP.description: Low economic active power limit that shall be greater than or equal to the minimum operating active power limit.

EnergyConsumer.normalParticipationFactor.description:
Participation factor describing the entity part of the active power provided by a collection of entities (e.g. an active power forecast to a collection of entities is divided to each of the member entity according to the participation factor). Must be a positive value.
In the case of a sharing strategy, the distribution is following entities value (V) equals aggregated value (T) divided by sum of participation factors (PF), i.e. V=T/sum(PF). 
In the case of priority strategy, the item with the lowest number gets allocated energy first.

EnergyCoordinationRegion.description: A region that has a common organisation or a service that is responsible for alignment of forecast and scheduling of energy.

EnergyCoordinationRegion.EnergyAlignment.description: The energy alignment coordinator that operates this energy coordination region.

EnergyExchangePoint.description:
An EnergyExchangePoint is a PointOfCommonCoupling that defines the electrical and operational interface between two independent adjacent grid operators —such as two TSOs, a TSO and a DSO, or two DSOs—who are responsible for coordinated operation of interconnected power systems.
It marks the electrical boundary point at which the energy exchange agreement between the two grid operators is enacted, and where power flows, balancing responsibilities, and observability requirements are formally managed. Operational conditions defined by applicable regulation—such as exchange capacity, frequency and voltage support, fault ride-through, protection coordination, and metering—can be defined at this point and in some cases enforced at this point.
It supports bidirectional power flow and may be associated with operational requirements such as balancing, frequency and voltage control, telemetry, protection coordination, and energy accounting.

EnergyGroup.description: An energy group is an aggregation of energy components which have the same energy characteristic, e.g. fuel type and technology. It can be used to allocate energy.

EnergyGroup.EnergyType.description: The energy type that the energy group are defined by.

EnergyGroup.SchedulingArea.description: The scheduling area that has this energy group.

EnergyGroup.normalParticipationFactor.description: Normal participation factor for the power group in relation to scheduling area. Must be a positive value.

EnergyType.description:
A source of the energy.

An energy type reference refers to an energy characteristic that is needed for reporting, e.g. European Energy Certificate System (EECS). The kind of energy should be possible to be linked with different type of energy forecast, e.g. wind production for a given area based on wind forecast.

EnergyType.EnergySourceReference.description: Energy source refrence which has energy type references.

EnergyKind.bufferConsumption.description: Flexibility in operation but bound to some buffering capability e.g. battery, electrical vehicle, cooling system, freezer.

EnergyKind.timeShiftConsumption.description: Operation can be shifted in time but can have a deadline e.g. washing machine, dishwasher.

EnergyKind.unconstrainedConsumption.description: Consumption is not constrained by any buffer and provides full flexibility. It is difficult to measure and to provide forecast. The consumption can be provided by local production. e.g. gas generator, diesel generator wood fire, etc.

EnergyKind.uncontrollableConsumption.description: Consumption where there is no flexibility and it is measurable and under possibility to provide a forecast. e.g. TV, indoor lightning.

EquivalentGeneratingUnit.description: An indivisible set of installations which can generate electrical energy such that the frequency of the generated voltage, the generator speed and the frequency of network voltage are in a constant ratio and thus in synchronism. This is often referred as synchronous power-generating module.

ActivePowerChangeRate.description: Rate of change of active power per time.

GeneratingUnit.lowerRampRate.description: The normal maximum rate the generating unit active power output can be lowered by control actions.

GeneratingUnit.maxEconomicP.description: Maximum high economic active power limit, that should not exceed the maximum operating active power limit.

GeneratingUnit.minEconomicP.description: Low economic active power limit that shall be greater than or equal to the minimum operating active power limit.

GeneratingUnit.minimumOffTime.description: Minimum time interval between unit shutdown and startup.

GeneratingUnit.raiseRampRate.description: The normal maximum rate the generating unit active power output can be raised by control actions.

EquivalentGeneratingUnit.EquivalentPower.description: Equivalent power plant that has this equivalent generating unit.

GeneratingUnit.ScheduleResource.description: The schedule resource that has this generating unit.

GeneratingUnit.coolDownTime.description: Time it takes from a unit shutdown until it is considered cold.

Currency.BMD.description: Bermudian dollar (customarily known as Bermuda dollar).

GeneratingUnit.costCurrency.description: Currency the cost is given in.

GeneratingUnit.maxRampDownCountPerDay.description: Number of times the unit can do ramp down within a calendar day. One ramp down consists of a decrease of a power plant production level from a stable schedule to another regardless of how much time the power plant stays in such stable operating stage.

GeneratingUnit.maxStartupLoad.description: Maximum consumption by the generating unit as part of the startup process.

GeneratingUnit.minimumUpTime.description: The time that a generating unit has to stay running after it has been switched on by the Remedial Action Optimizer.

GeneratingUnit.normalMustRunP.description: Normal minimum active power injection that is needed to meet must-run requirement. This value can be higher or equal to minimum operational limit. Load sign convention is used, i.e. positive sign means flow out from a node.

ReactivePower.description: Product of RMS value of the voltage and the RMS value of the quadrature component of the current.

GeneratingUnit.normalMustRunQ.description: Normal minimum reactive power injection that is needed to meet must-run requirement. This value can be higher or equal to minimum operational limit. Load sign convention is used, i.e. positive sign means flow out from a node.

Decimal.description: Decimal is the base-10 notational system for representing real numbers.

GeneratingUnit.normalShutdownCost.description: The normal shutdown cost incurred for each shutdown of the GeneratingUnit.

GeneratingUnit.normalStartupCost.description: The normal initial startup cost incurred for each start of the GeneratingUnit.

GeneratingUnit.normalWarmStartupCost.description: The normal warm startup cost incurred for each start of the GeneratingUnit.

GeneratingUnit.rampLockTime.description: Time between end or start of ramping. If a unit has just stopped the ramping, it will need to wait this time until a new ramping can start.

GeneratingUnit.runningLeadTime.description: Time it takes to change the schedule when the unit is operating due to technical configuration of a supporting system, e.g. gas pipeline.

GeneratingUnit.shutdownTime.description: Time it takes to shutdown the unit.

GeneratingUnit.startupRampRate.description:
The startup ramp rate of the generating unit which describes the speed of change of active power from zero to the minimum active power.
When the ramp is not provided, the optimisation process shall consider the change as an instant change of active power from zero to minimum active power.

GeneratingUnit.warmStartupTime.description: Time it takes to startup the unit when it is warm.

EquivalentInjection.description: This class represents equivalent injections (generation or load).  Voltage regulation is allowed only at the point of connection.

EquivalentInjection.InjectionController.description: Injection controller which controls the equivalent injection.

EquivalentPowerElectronicsUnit.description: An equivalent unit or ensemble of units generating electricity, which is either non-synchronously connected to the network or connected through power electronics, and that also has a single connection point to a transmission system, distribution system including closed distribution system or an equivalent representation of a HVDC system. This is often referred as power park module.

EquivalentPowerElectronicsUnit.Equivalen.description: Equivalent power plan that has this equivalent power electronics unit.

EquivalentPowerPlant.description: Collection of equivalent equipment for purposes of generation.

ExceptionalPowerTransferCorridor.description: Potential power transfer corridor that can be triggered by equipment which changes its in service status or it is operating in an island.

PowerTransferCorridor.normalEnabled.description: It is the normal enable/disable the monitoring/assessment of a power transfer corridor. True means that the monitoring of the power transfer corridor is assessed. False means the power transfer corridor is not assessed.

ExternalNetworkInjection.description: This class represents the external network and it is used for IEC 60909 calculations.

ExternalNetworkInjection.maxP.description: Maximum active power of the injection.

ExternalNetworkInjection.maxQ.description: Maximum reactive power limit. It is used for modelling of infeed for load flow exchange and not for short circuit modelling.

ExternalNetworkInjection.minP.description: Minimum active power of the injection.

ExternalNetworkInjection.minQ.description: Minimum reactive power limit. It is used for modelling of infeed for load flow exchange and not for short circuit modelling.

ExternalNetworkInjection.EquivalentGener.description: Equivalent generating unit that has this external network injection.

RegulatingCondEq.EquipmentController.description: The equipment controller for this regulating conducting equipment.

FlexibleEnergyUnit.description: Flexible consumer or embedded producer of energy. The unit cannot be a net producer.

FlexibleEnergyUnit.buffer.description: The active power, that has the flexibility to operate as production and/or consumption. The buffer is bound. Example are heat pump, cooling system, embedded batteries including electric vehicle. Load sign convention is used, i.e. positive sign means flow out from a node.

FlexibleEnergyUnit.timeShift.description: The active power, that can be shifted from one pricing interval (market time unit) to another. It is expected to be a limited on the length of the shift. Example from household could be washing machine or dishwasher. Example from industry is the possible to shut down a machine for the relevant period. Load sign convention is used, i.e. positive sign means flow out from a node.

FlexibleEnergyUnit.unconstrained.description: The active power, that has the flexibility to operate as production without any bound by a buffer. Example are alternative heating (wood, gas, diesel etc) or power generators. Load sign convention is used, i.e. positive sign means flow out from a node.

FlexibleEnergyUnit.uncontrollable.description: The active power, that forms the base consumption for the unit. This is measured and expected consumption. Load sign convention is used, i.e. positive sign means flow out from a node.

FossilFuel.description: The fossil fuel consumed by the non-nuclear thermal generating unit.   For example, coal, oil, gas, etc.   These are the specific fuels that the generating unit can consume.

FossilFuel.FuelStorage.description: Fuel storage that store fossil fuels.

FrequencyControlFunction.description: Frequency control function is a function block that calculate the operating point of the controlled equipment to achieve the target frequency.

FrequencyMonitoringTerminal.description: Frequency monitoring terminal provides location in the model where the frequency is monitored for the purpose of power frequency control.

FrequencyMonitoringTerminal.PowerFrequen.description: Power frequency controller that has this frequency monitoring terminal.

FrequencyMonitoringTerminal.Terminal.description: The terminal for this frequency monitoring terminal.

FrequencyMonitoringTerminal.mRID.description:
Master resource identifier issued by a model authority. The mRID is unique within an exchange context. Global uniqueness is easily achieved by using a UUID, as specified in RFC 4122, for the mRID. The use of UUID is strongly recommended.
For CIMXML data files in RDF syntax conforming to IEC 61970-552, the mRID is mapped to rdf:ID or rdf:about attributes that identify CIM object elements.

FrequencyMonitoringTerminal.priority.description: Value 0 means ignore priority. 1 means the highest priority, 2 is the second highest priority.

FuelStorage.description: Fuel storage. e.g. pile of coal that can be shared between multiple thermal generating units.

FuelStorage.normalEnergyStorage.description: Normal amount of energy available in the storage.

FunctionOutputVariable.description: Functional output variable defines the codomain of the function.

FunctionOutputVariable.FunctionBlock.description: Function block describe the function that function output variable provides the codomain for.

FunctionOutputVariable.PropertyReference.description: Property reference refers to a given class and property that is populated by the function output variable.

GateInputPin.description: Input pin for a logical gate. The condition described in the input pin gives a logical true or false. The result from measurement and calculation are converted to a true or false.

FunctionInputVariable.Function.description: Function block describe the function that function input variable provides the domain for.

GateInputPin.absoluteValue.description: Indicates if the absolute value is used for comparison. If true, use the absolute value. If false, use the complex value (vector).

GateInputPin.duration.description: The time duration for which the condition is satisfied before acting. Default is 0 seconds.

LogicalOperatorsKind.greaterThanOrEquals.description: Greater than or equals comparison operation.

LogicalOperatorsKind.lessThanOrEquals.description: Less than or equals comparison operation.

GateInputPin.logicKind.description: The logical operator kind used for comparison.

GateInputPin.negate.description: Invert/negate the result of the comparison.

GateInputPin.thresholdPercentage.description:
The threshold percentage that should be used for compare with the percentage change between input value and threshold value.
The allowed value range is [0,100].

GateInputPin.thresholdValue.description: The threshold value that should be used for compare with the input value.

GeneratingUnit.description: A single or set of synchronous machines for converting mechanical power into alternating-current power. For example, individual machines within a set may be defined for scheduling purposes while a single control signal is derived for the set. In this case there would be a GeneratingUnit for each member of the set and an additional GeneratingUnit corresponding to the set.

GeothermalGeneratingUnit.description: Generating unit that is generating electrical power from geothermal energy.

GeothermalUnitKind.binaryCycle.description: The moderately hot geothermal water is passed by a secondary fluid with a much lower boiling point than water.

GeothermalUnitKind.drySteam.description: Uses geothermal steam of 150 degree Celsius or greater to turn turbines.

GeothermalUnitKind.flashSteam.description: Pull deep, high-pressure hot water into lower-pressure tanks and use the resulting flashed steam to drive turbines.

GeothermalUnitKind.other.description: Other type of geothermal generating unit.

GridConnectionPoint.description:
A GridConnectionPoint is a Point of Common Coupling (PCC) that defines the contractual and operational interface between a grid operator (e.g., TSO, DSO, or CDSO) and a connecting entity, such as a person, company, prosumer, or facility operator.
It represents the electrical location at which the connection agreement—as defined by applicable grid connection codes (e.g., EU RfG, DCC, HVDC)—is enacted, establishing the technical, legal, and compliance boundaries for power exchange between the public grid and the connected installation or energy system.
All operational conditions required by regulation—such as voltage and frequency ranges, fault ride-through capabilities, power quality limits, and observability—are applicable at this point.
The GridConnectionPoint may support bidirectional power flow, and is typically associated with metering, disconnection, and protection devices, but is independent of voltage level or specific technology.

HydroPowerPlant.description: A hydro power station which can generate or pump. When generating, the generator turbines receive water from an upper reservoir. When pumping, the pumps receive their water from a lower reservoir.

HydroPowerPlant.Reservoir.description: Generators discharge water to or pumps are supplied water from a downstream reservoir.

HydroPump.description: A synchronous motor-driven pump, typically associated with a pumped storage plant.

HydroPump.ScheduleResource.description: The schedule resource that has this hydro pump.

HydroPump.maxEconomicP.description: Maximum high economic active power limit, that should not exceed the maximum operating active power limit.

HydroPump.maxOperatingP.description: This is the maximum operating active power limit the dispatcher can enter for this unit.

HydroPump.minEconomicP.description: Low economic active power limit that shall be greater than or equal to the minimum operating active power limit.

HydroPump.minOperatingP.description: This is the minimum operating active power limit the dispatcher can enter for this unit.

HydroPump.normalParticipationFactor.description:
Participation factor describing the entity part of the active power provided by a collection of entities (e.g. an active power forecast to a collection of entities is divided to each of the member entity according to the participation factor). Must be a positive value.
In the case of a sharing strategy, the distribution is following entities value (V) equals aggregated value (T) divided by sum of participation factors (PF), i.e. V=T/sum(PF). 
In the case of priority strategy, the item with the lowest number gets allocated energy first.

ImpedanceControlFunction.description: Impedance control function is a function block that calculates the operating point of the controlled equipment to achieve the target impedance.

InfeedLimit.description: Infeed limit set constraints fed in to the network by two or more terminals.

OperationalLimit.OperationalLimitSet.description: The limit set to which the limit values belong.

OperationalLimit.OperationalLimitType.description: The limit type associated with this limit.

InfeedLimit.normalValueA.description: The normal current limit. The attribute shall be a positive value or zero.

InfeedLimit.normalValueW.description: The normal value of active power limit. The attribute shall be a positive value or zero.

InfeedTerminal.description: Infeed terminal defines the terminals that are linked to an infeed limit.

InfeedTerminal.ACDCTerminal.description: ACDCTerminal which is connected to an infeed terminal.

InfeedTerminal.InfeedConstraint.description: Infeed constraint which belongs to an infeed terminal.

InfeedTerminal.mRID.description:
Master resource identifier issued by a model authority. The mRID is unique within an exchange context. Global uniqueness is easily achieved by using a UUID, as specified in RFC 4122, for the mRID. The use of UUID is strongly recommended.
For CIMXML data files in RDF syntax conforming to IEC 61970-552, the mRID is mapped to rdf:ID or rdf:about attributes that identify CIM object elements.

InjectionController.description: Injection controller is controlling the equipment which represents an injection or an external network.

Installation.description:
An Installation represents a functionally integrated system at a premises or facility that is connected to an energy infrastructure, but is not itself an energy device (e.g., generator, load, or storage).
It serves as a system-level abstraction of the internal infrastructure—such as intake cable, switchboards, internal cabling, distribution panels, protection devices, and auxiliary equipment —that enables and constraints the connection to one or more energy connections (electrical, thermal, gas, etc.).

Installations are typically owned and operated by the site holder, not the utility, and exist within buildings, industrial sites, or campus.

Installation.EdgeSchedulingArea.description: The edge scheduling area for this installation.

Installation.EnergyConnection.description: The energy connection that is connected to the installation.

Line.description: Contains equipment beyond a substation belonging to a power transmission line.

Line.ACTieCorridor.description: ACTieCorridor that the line is part of.

Line.SchedulingArea.description: The scheduling area that has this line.

LineCircuit.description: A line circuit is a circuit that has at least one ACLineSegment and may or may not include related switching and/or auxiliary equipment.

LoadFrequencyControlArea.description: A part of a synchronous area or an entire synchronous area, physically demarcated by points of measurement at interconnectors to other load frequency control (LFC) areas, operated by one or more TSOs fulfilling the obligations of load-frequency control.

LoadFrequencyControlArea.FrequencyContro.description: The frequency control operator that operates this frequency control area.

LoadFrequencyControlArea.LoadFrequencyCo.description: The load frequency control block that has this load frequency control area.

LoadFrequencyControlArea.deficientGenera.description: Percentage of average dispatch target plus average regulation used to calculate  Deficient Generation Limit. The value shall be a positive value between 0 and 100.

LoadFrequencyControlArea.frequencyRestor.description: FRR delay expressed in seconds. Must be a positive multiple of AGC's cycle duration.
Maximum authorized ramp for both FRR dispatching and ramp to zero.
Authorized threshold for both FRR dispatching and ramp to zero.

LoadFrequencyControlArea.includeFrequenc.description: True means the frequency bias that is taken into consideration in the frequency bias computation.

LoadFrequencyControlBlock.description: A part of a synchronous area or an entire synchronous area, physically demarcated by points of measurement at interconnectors to other load frequency control (LFC) blocks, consisting of one or more LFC areas, operated by one or more TSOs fulfilling the obligations of load-frequency control.

LoadFrequencyControlBlock.SynchronousAre.description: The synchronous area that has this load frequency control block.

LoadFrequencyControlOperator.description: A role that is responsible for operational security by operating the load frequency control (LFC) mechanism.

LossCurve.description: Represents the losses in the equipment due to operation position.

LossCurve.FACTSEquipment.description: The FACTS equipment which has a loss curve.

MobileElectricalUnit.description:
A MobileElectricalUnit represents a persistent power system resource that can act as a source or sink of electrical energy within the grid. It is designed to interface with the grid through defined connection points for charging or discharging, while the physical energy storage asset associated with it (e.g., an electric vehicle or battery trailer) may be mobile. The MobileElectricalUnit abstracts the system-side functionality of mobile energy storage, independent of specific assets or charging events. It typically stores electrical energy in batteries or equivalent storage media and supports flexible, temporary, or location-variable integration into the power system. Examples include, but are not limited to:
  • Electric vehicles (EVs)
  • Electrically powered ferries
  • Trailer-based battery storage units
  • Mobile battery systems for backup or temporary grid support
  • This concept supports consistent modeling of mobile energy systems in grid studies by treating the grid-facing connection as a stable power system element, while the associated physical unit is managed as an asset.

MobileElectricalUnit.ElectricalChargingU.description: Electrical charging unit that has a mobile electrical unit.

ModularStaticSynchronousSeriesCompensato.description: Modular static synchronous series compensator (MSSSC) is a type of flexible AC transmission system regulating equipment which consists of solid-state voltage source inverter connected in series with a transmission line. This is similar to static synchronous series compensator (SSSC), but without injection transformer. This enables the MSSSC to be truly modular with the ability to simply install a number of equipment in series to provide a desired maximum level of impedance. MSSSC can be dispersed into multiple location in a circuit working collectively under the same controller scheme.

Reactance.description: Reactance (imaginary part of impedance), at rated frequency.

FACTSEquipment.maxC.description: Capacitive reactance at maximum reactive power.  Shall always be positive.

FACTSEquipment.maxL.description: Inductive rating at maximum inductive reactive power.  Shall always be negative.

FACTSEquipment.minC.description: Capacitive reactance at minimum reactive power.  Shall always be positive.

FACTSEquipment.minL.description: Inductive rating at minimum inductive reactive power.  Shall always be negative.

FACTSEquipment.ratedC.description: Capacitive reactance at maximum reactive power.  Shall always be positive.

FACTSEquipment.ratedI.description: Rated current of the FACTS equipment.

FACTSEquipment.ratedL.description: Inductive rating at maximum inductive reactive power.  Shall always be negative.

Voltage.description: Electrical voltage, can be both AC and DC.

FACTSEquipment.ratedU.description: Rated voltage of the FACTS equipment.

FACTSEquipment.slope.description:
The characteristics slope which defines how the reactive power output changes in proportion to the difference between the regulated bus voltage and the voltage setpoint.
The attribute shall be a positive value or zero.

MonopolarDCSystem.description: Monopolar DC system (IEC 60633) is a DC system with only one pole.

MonopolarDCSystem.isSymmetrical.description: if true, the monopolar DC system is symmetrical monopolar DC system (IEC 60633). It is a DC system with only one symmetrical monopole. A symmetrical monopole is part of an DC system consisting of all the equipment in the DC substations and the interconnecting transmission lines, if any, which during normal operation exhibits equal and opposite direct voltage polarities with respect to earth but without series connection of converters in each converter station. The term "symmetrical monopole" is used even though there are two polarities with DC voltages, because with only one converter it is not possible to provide the redundancy which is normally associated with the term "bipole".

NuclearReactorKind.breeder.description: Reactor whose heat source is a nuclear reactor that generates more fissile material than it consumes.

NuclearReactorKind.graphite.description: Reactor whose heat source is a graphite-moderated reactor that is a nuclear reactor that uses carbon as a neutron moderator, which allows natural uranium to be used as nuclear fuel.

NuclearReactorKind.heavyWater.description: Reactor whose heat source is a pressurized heavy-water reactor (PHWR) that uses heavy water (deuterium oxide D2O) as its coolant and neutron moderator.

NuclearReactorKind.lightWater.description: Reactor whose heat source is a light-water reactor (LWR) that is a type of thermal-neutron reactor that uses normal water, as both its coolant and neutron moderator – furthermore a solid form of fissile elements is used as fuel.

NuclearReactorKind.liquidMetal.description: Reactor whose liquid metal cooled nuclear reactor, liquid metal fast reactor or LMFR is an advanced type of nuclear reactor where the primary coolant is a liquid metal.

OperationalLimitSet.description: A set of limits associated with equipment.  Sets of limits might apply to a specific temperature, or season for example. A set of limits may contain different severities of limit levels that would apply to the same equipment. The set may contain limits of different types such as apparent power and current limits or high and low voltage limits  that are logically applied together as a set.

OperationalLimitSet.Terminal.description: The terminal where the operational limit set apply.

OperationalLimitSet.PowerTransferCorrido.description: The power transfer corridor that has this operational limit set.

OperationalLimitType.description: The operational meaning of a category of limits.

OperationalLimitDirectionKind.absoluteVa.description: An absoluteValue limit means that a monitored absolute value above the limit value is a violation.

OperationalLimitDirectionKind.high.description: High means that a monitored value above the limit value is a violation.   If applied to a terminal flow, the positive direction is into the terminal.

OperationalLimitDirectionKind.low.description: Low means a monitored value below the limit is a violation.  If applied to a terminal flow, the positive direction is into the terminal.

OperationalLimitType.PermanentAmbientTem.description: The permanent ambient temperature dependency curve for this operational limit type.

OperationalLimitType.PermanentSolarRadia.description: The permanent solar radiation curve for this operational limit type.

OperationalLimitType.RecoveryOverloadLim.description: This is the curve which provides the recovery time information for this limit type.

OperationalLimitType.TemporaryBaseOverlo.description: The temporary base overload limit curve for this operational limit type.

OperationalLimitType.TemporaryDurationOv.description: The temporary duration overload limit curve for this operational limit type.

OperationalLimitType.isMinimum.description: Defines if the operational limit type is minimum. If true, the value is a minimum value of the same kind. This applies to stability and PATL. If false, the limit has the normal behaviour. OperationalLimitType.direction attribute shall be absoluteValue.

OrdinaryPowerTransferCorridor.description: Power transfer corridor defined for normal operating network.

Organisation.description: Organisation that might have roles as utility, contractor, supplier, manufacturer, customer, etc.

OutageCoordinationRegion.description: A region that has a common organisation or service responsible for outage planning and coordination and its impact on grid operation.

OutageCoordinationRegion.OutageCoordinat.description: The outage coordinator responsible for this outage coordination region.

OutageCoordinationRegion.SecurityCoordin.description: The security coordinator that is responsible for this outage coordination region.

OutageCoordinator.description: A role that coordinates the planned availability status of relevant power system equipment to meet the need by the asset owner or operator and the security of the power system.

OutagePlanningAgent.description: An entity with the task of planning the availability status of a relevant power generating module, a relevant demand facility or a relevant grid element.

OutagePlanningAgent.OutageCoordinationRe.description: Outage coordination region that this agent has outage planning responsible.

OverlappingZone.description: A collection of all the overlapping cross border assessed elements which have the same sets of impacted and impacting regions.

PTCTriggeredEquipment.description: Power Transfer Corridor triggered equipment connects the equipment that will create the exceptional power transfer corridor when taking out of service. e.g. A system with three lines gets an exceptional power transfer corridor when one of the lines is taken out of service.

PTCTriggeredEquipment.Equipment.description: The equipment which is part of power transfer corridor triggering.

PTCTriggeredEquipment.ExceptionalPowerTr.description: The power transfer corridor which is triggered by this equipment.

PhaseControlFunction.description: Phase control function is a function block that calculate the operating point of the controlled equipment to achieve the target voltage.

PinTerminal.description: Input pin associated with a Terminal. It is used for comparison.

PinTerminal.Terminal.description: The Terminal that is used in the input pin.

PinTerminal.kind.description: The kind of quantity which is used as an input value.

PowerCapacity.description: Power capacity defines the capacity in regard to generation, consumption and transmission (import and export) for a relevant power system resource, e.g. bidding zone, including maximum and minimum electrical power capacity and any capacity allocation.

PowerElectricalChemicalUnit.description: A unit capable of either generating electrical energy from chemical reactions or using electrical energy to cause chemical reactions.

PowerElectricalChemicalUnitKind.electrol.description: An electrolytic cell is an electrochemical cell that drives a non-spontaneous redox reaction through the application of electrical energy. Example are the decomposition of water into hydrogen and oxygen.

PowerElectricalChemicalUnitKind.fuelCell.description: A fuel cell is an electrochemical cell that converts the chemical energy from a fuel into electricity through an electrochemical reaction of hydrogen fuel with oxygen or another oxidizing agent.

PowerElectricalChemicalUnitKind.other.description: Other type of cell used in chemical reactions.

PowerElectricalChemicalUnit.kind.description: Kind of power electrical chemical unit.

PowerElectronicsConnectionController.description: Power electronics connection controller is controlling the equipment to optimize the power electronics connection.

PowerElectronicsMarineUnit.description: A unit that capture energy from marine sources, e.g. waves, for generating electrical power.

MarineUnitKind.currents.description: Capture energy from ocean current which are caused by forces like breaking waves, wind, coriolis effect etc.

MarineUnitKind.other.description: Other way of capture energy from marine elements.

MarineUnitKind.tidal.description: Capture energy from tidal power, which captures the energy of the current caused by the gravitational pull of the Sun and Moon.

PowerElectronicsUnit.description: A generating unit or battery or aggregation that connects to the AC network using power electronics rather than rotating machines.

PowerElectronicsUnitController.description: Power electronics unit controller is controlling the equipment to optimize the power electronics unit.

PowerElectronicsUnitController.PowerElec.description: Power electronics connection controller for the power electronics unit controller.

PowerFactorControlFunction.description: Power factor control function is a function block that calculates the operating point of the controlled equipment to achieve the target power factor.

PowerFrequencyController.description: Power frequency controller is controlling the active power balance as typically done by the secondary control. If an unbalance between the scheduled active power values of each generation unit and the loads plus losses occurs, primary control will adapt (increase/decrease) the active power production of each unit (depending on the power shift key strategy), leading to an over- or under-frequency situation. The secondary frequency controller will then control the frequency back to its nominal value, re- establishing a cost-efficient generation delivered by each unit.

PowerFrequencyController.ControlArea.description: Control area which has a power frequency controller.

PowerFrequencyController.MonitoringArea.description: Monitoring area that has this power frequency controller.

PowerFrequencyController.PowerShiftKeySt.description: Power shift key strategy for this power frequency controller.

PowerFrequencyControlKind.activePowerAnd.description: Active power and frequency control mode.

PowerFrequencyController.mode.description: Mode of the power frequency controller.

PowerPlantController.description: Power plant controller is controlling the equipment of a power plant.

PowerShiftKeyStrategy.description: Strategy of the power shift key.

PowerShiftKeyStrategy.SchedulingArea.description: Scheduling area associated with power shift key strategy.

PowerShiftKeyStrategy.dispatchableUnitOn.description:
If true, only dispatchable units are included in the power shift key strategy. A unit is considered dispatchable if it is associated with an area dispatchable unit that is linked to the same scheduling area as the power shift key strategy.
Exceptions are done for units that are included in explicit or distributed strategies.

ShiftMethodKind.priority.description: Power schedule shift (distribution) is done by a shared fraction prioritizing the unit e.g. A two unit with the participation factor 60 and 40 will distribute a 10 MW increased schedule by first filling the highest participation factor (priority) until max economy power or maximum power allowed by the unit before it starts filling the next on the list. e.g. The unit with 60 will be getting its maximum shared first. The same logic applies with reducing the schedule. e.g. The 60 participation factor unit will be reduced to its min economy factor or minimum power.

ShiftMethodKind.shared.description: Power schedule shift (distribution) is done by a shared fraction e.g. A two unit with the participation factor 60 and 40 will distribute a 10 MW schedule by 6 and 4 MW.

PowerShiftKeyStrategy.method.description: Shift method used for the power shift strategy.

PowerShiftKeyStrategy.normalEnabled.description: If true, the assessed element shall be considered under normal operating conditions.

PowerShiftKeyStrategy.normalParticipatio.description: Normal participation factor describing the entities part of the power shift strategy. Must be a positive value.

PowerBlockKind.powerDecrease.description: Decrease in the power. The block represents action for decreased power.

PowerBlockKind.powerIncrease.description: Increase in the power. The block represents action for increased power.

PowerBlockKind.powerIncreaseAndDecrease.description: Increase and decrease in the power. The block represents action for increased and decreased power.

PowerShiftKeyStrategy.powerBlockKind.description: Power block kind creates block (one or more) of power shift key strategy to address increase and/or decrease of power for a given scheduling area.

PowerShiftKeyKind.consumptionsFlat.description: Flat adjustment, equal amount of power, on all active consumption units (Energy Consumers and Power Electronics like FlexibleEnergyUnit). e.g. 100 MW decrease adjustment on 4 loads, it means that each of them get reduced 25 MW, as long as no other constraints are violated.

PowerShiftKeyKind.consumptionsP.description: The distribution is based on the consumptions active power in the given case.

PowerShiftKeyKind.explicitDistribution.description: The distribution is explicitly done according to the power shift key  distribution in the power bid Schedule.

PowerShiftKeyKind.explicitInstruction.description: The distribution is done according to the individual participation factor on the unit.

PowerShiftKeyKind.generatorsAndConsumpti.description: The distribution is based on the generator and consumption active power in the given case.

PowerShiftKeyKind.generatorsFlat.description: Flat adjustment, equal amount of power, on all active generators. e.g. 100 MW increase adjustment on 4 generators, it means that each of them get increased 25 MW, as long as no other constraints are violated.

PowerShiftKeyKind.generatorsP.description: The distribution is based on the generators active power in the given case.

PowerShiftKeyKind.generatorsPmax.description: The distribution is relative to the maximum p of the generator.

PowerShiftKeyKind.generatorsPmin.description: The distribution is relative to the minimum p of the generator.

PowerShiftKeyKind.generatorsRemainingCap.description: The distribution is based on the remaining capacity for generators in the given case.

PowerShiftKeyKind.generatorsUsedCapacity.description: The distribution is based on the used capacity, the difference between the minimum operation and operating p (GeneratingUnit.minOperatingP)

PowerShiftKeyKind.nonConformLoadP.description: The distribution is based on the non conform load active power in the given case.

PowerShiftKeyKind.storageFlat.description: Flat adjustment, equal amount of power, on all the batteries and any operating hydro pumps. e.g. 100 MW increase or decrease adjustment on 4 batteries, it means that each of them get increased or reduced 25 MW, as long as no other constraints are violated.

PowerShiftKeyKind.storageP.description: The distribution is based on the batteries and any operating hydro pumps active power in the given case.

PowerShiftKeyStrategy.powerShiftKey.description: Power shift keys strategy gives instruction on how the value (Active power) is going to be distributed inside the relevant bidding zone.

PowerTransformerCircuit.description: A power transformer circuit is a circuit that has at least one PowerTransformer and may or may not include related switching and/or auxiliary equipment.

ProportionalEnergyComponent.description: Serves for grouping components within an energy group, with proportional energy allocation to all components.

ReactiveCapabilityCurve.description: Reactive power rating envelope versus the synchronous machine's active power, in both the generating and motoring modes. For each active power value there is a corresponding high and low reactive power limit  value. Typically there will be a separate curve for each coolant condition, such as hydrogen pressure.  The Y1 axis values represent reactive minimum and the Y2 axis values represent reactive maximum.

Temperature.description: Value of temperature in degrees Celsius.

ReactiveCapabilityCurve.coolantTemperatu.description: The machine's coolant temperature (e.g., ambient air or stator circulating water).

ReactiveCapabilityCurve.EquivalentInject.description: The equivalent injection using this reactive capability curve.

ReactiveCapabilityCurve.operatingMode.description: The operating mode of synchronous machine for which the reactive capability curve is valid for. In case the attribute is not provided it is assumed that the reactive capability curve covers all possible operating modes of the synchronous machine.

ReactiveCapabilityCurve.referenceVoltage.description: The reference voltage for which the capability curve is valid.

ReactivePowerControlFunction.description: Reactive power control function is a function block that calculate the operating point of the controlled equipment to achieve the target reactive power.

RecoveryOverloadLimitCurve.description: The relation between the recovery time and an overload limit.

Reservoir.description: A water storage facility within a hydro system, including: ponds, lakes, lagoons, and rivers. The storage is usually behind some type of dam.

Reservoir.normalEnergyStorage.description: Normal amount of energy available in the storage.

RotatingMachineController.description: Rotating machine controller is controlling the equipment which may be used as a generator or motor.

SSSCController.description: The controller of a Static synchronous series compensator (SSSC).

SSSCController.SSSCSimulationSettings.description: The simulation setings that apply for this controller.

SSSCController.maxInjectionU.description: Maximum voltage that the device can inject.

SSSCController.maxLimitI.description: Maximum operating current limit applied for the controller and used by any of the available control functions.

SSSCController.minInjectionU.description: Minimum voltage that the device can inject.

SSSCController.minLimitI.description: Minimum operating current limit applied for the controller and used by any of the available control functions.

SSSCSimulationSettings.description: SSSC control simulation settings used by the algorithm for power flow calculations.

SSSCSimulationSettings.deltaX.description: Reactance delta for the solution algorithm. The solution “outer-loop” algorithm is based on a secant method which needs two initial points. The second point is calculated from the first one by either adding or subtracting this “delta”. The “seed” is assumed to be 0 ohms.

SSSCSimulationSettings.isEstimateDLDVSen.description: Defines if the estimate is considering the dI/dV sensitivity (true) instead of the secant algorithm (false).

SSSCSimulationSettings.mRID.description:
Master resource identifier issued by a model authority. The mRID is unique within an exchange context. Global uniqueness is easily achieved by using a UUID, as specified in RFC 4122, for the mRID. The use of UUID is strongly recommended.
For CIMXML data files in RDF syntax conforming to IEC 61970-552, the mRID is mapped to rdf:ID or rdf:about attributes that identify CIM object elements.

SSSCSimulationSettings.maxCorrectionX.description: Maximum value of the reactance correction applied between Iterations of the power flow calculation algorithm for the purpose of achieving control target value.

SSSCSimulationSettings.maxIterations.description: Maximum number of iterations before claiming an open line condition. The algorithm uses it to assess if a line is really open by making sure low-currents are observed on various consecutive iterations.

SSSCSimulationSettings.maxMismatch.description: Maximum mismatch tolerance of voltage target value. If mismatch is lower, convergence is claimed. It is only used for voltageInjection and currentDroop control modes.

ScheduleResource.description: A schedule resource is a market-based method for handling participation of small units, particularly located on the lower voltage level that is controlled by a Distributed System Operator (DSO). It is a collection of units that can operate in the market by providing bids, offers and a resulting committed operational schedule for the collection.

ScheduleResource.PrimaryEnergySource.description: Primary energy reference type for this schedule resource.

ScheduleResource.ResourceOf.description: The schedule resource that has this subschedule resource.

ScheduleResource.ScheduleResourceControl.description: Schedule resource controller for this schedule resource.

ScheduleResource.SchedulingArea.description: The scheduling area that has this schedule resource.

ScheduleResourceController.description: Schedule resource controller is controlling the equipment to optimize the schedule resource.

SchedulingArea.description: An area where production and/or consumption of energy can be forecasted, scheduled and measured. The area is operated by only one system operator, typically a Transmission System Operator (TSO). The area can consist of a sub area, which has the same definition as the main area, but it can be operated by another system operator (typically Distributed System Operator (DSO) or a Closed Distributed System Operator (CDSO)). This includes microgrid concept. A substation is the smallest grouping that can be included in the area. The area size should be considered in terms of the possibility of accumulated reading (settlement metering) and the capability of operating as an island.

SchedulingAreaExchangePoint.description: Combination of scheduling area and one or more energy exchange point to define the relevant exchange point for a given scheduling area.

SchedulingAreaExchangePoint.EnergyExchan.description: The energy exchange point associated with the scheduling area.

SchedulingAreaExchangePoint.SchedulingAr.description: The scheduling area that has a scheduling area exchange point.

SchedulingAreaExchangePoint.mRID.description:
Master resource identifier issued by a model authority. The mRID is unique within an exchange context. Global uniqueness is easily achieved by using a UUID, as specified in RFC 4122, for the mRID. The use of UUID is strongly recommended.
For CIMXML data files in RDF syntax conforming to IEC 61970-552, the mRID is mapped to rdf:ID or rdf:about attributes that identify CIM object elements.

SecondarySubstation.description:
A SecondarySubstation is a substation that is either supplied by or serves a primary substation. It is responsible for transforming, distributing, or aggregating power to and from installations such as homes, industrial facilities, or prosumer sites.
A secondary substation supports bidirectional power flows, enabling both consumption and injection of energy within the distribution network.
It typically includes transformers, switchgear, protection, and measurement equipment, and may be equipped for remote monitoring or autonomous control

SecondarySubstation.PrimarySubstation.description: The primary substation that serves the secondary substation.

SecondarySubstation.SubSchedulingArea.description: The subscheduling area that has the secondary substation connected.

Substation.SchedulingArea.description: The scheduling area that has this substation.

SecurityCoordinator.description: A role that coordinates the relevant remedial actions and their optimisation to ensure efficient use to achieve required operational security of the power system.

SolarRadiationDependencyCurve.description:
A curve or functional relationship between 
- the solar radiation independent variable (X-axis), and 
- relative dependent (Y-axis) variables.

StaticSynchronousCompensator.description: Static synchronous compensator (STATCOM), also known as a static synchronous condenser (STATCON), is a type of flexible AC transmission system regulating equipment used on alternating current electricity transmission networks. It is based on a power electronics voltage-source converter and can act as either a source or sink of reactive AC power to an electricity network. If connected to a source of power it can also provide active AC power.

StaticSynchronousSeriesCompensator.description: Static synchronous series compensator (SSSC) is a type of flexible AC transmission system which consists of a solid-state voltage source inverter coupled with a transformer that is connected in series with a transmission line. This device can inject an almost sinusoidal voltage in series with the line. This injected voltage could be considered as an inductive or capacitive reactance, which is connected in series with the transmission line. This feature can provide controllable voltage compensation. In addition, SSSC is able to reverse the power flow by injecting a sufficiently large series reactive compensating voltage. Moreover it can inject a voltage proportional to the difference between the line current and the pre-configured current threshold.<font color="#636671"> </font>It shall have two Terminal-s associated with it.

StaticVarCompensator.description:
A facility for providing variable and controllable shunt reactive power. The SVC typically consists of a stepdown transformer, filter, thyristor-controlled reactor, and thyristor-switched capacitor arms.

The SVC may operate in fixed MVar output mode or in voltage control mode. When in voltage control mode, the output of the SVC will be proportional to the deviation of voltage at the controlled bus from the voltage setpoint.  The SVC characteristic slope defines the proportion.  If the voltage at the controlled bus is equal to the voltage setpoint, the SVC MVar output is zero.

SubControlArea.description: A SubControlArea representing the operational control domain within a higher-level control area. It is typically operated by a Distribution System Operator (DSO) and covers the monitoring, control, scheduling, and application of operational limits for distribution system resources and exchanges at its boundary.

SubSchedulingArea.description: An area that is a part of another scheduling area. Typically part of a Transmission System Operator (TSO) scheduling area operated by a Distributed System Operator (DSO) or a Close Distributed System Operator (CDSO). This includes microgrid concept. A sub scheduling area can contain other sub areas. A sub scheduling area leaf will form the smallest entity of any given energy area.

Substation.description: A collection of equipment for purposes other than generation or utilization, through which electric energy in bulk is passed for the purposes of switching or modifying its characteristics.

SubstationController.description: Substation controller is controlling the equipment to optimize the use of the controlling equipment within a substation.

SynchronousArea.description: A synchronous area is an electrical area covered by interconnect with a common system frequency in a steady-state.

SynchronousArea.nominalFrequency.description: The nominal frequency for the Synchronous Area, e.g. 50 Hz for Europe.

TCSCCompensationPoint.description: Compensation point of a TCSC compensator.

TCSCCompensationPoint.ThyristorControlle.description: TCSC that has different compensation points.

TCSCCompensationPoint.compensationZ.description: The compensation impedance for this compensation point.

TCSCCompensationPoint.mRID.description:
Master resource identifier issued by a model authority. The mRID is unique within an exchange context. Global uniqueness is easily achieved by using a UUID, as specified in RFC 4122, for the mRID. The use of UUID is strongly recommended.
For CIMXML data files in RDF syntax conforming to IEC 61970-552, the mRID is mapped to rdf:ID or rdf:about attributes that identify CIM object elements.

TCSCController.description: TCSC controller is controlling the equipment to optimize the performance of the TCSC.

TapChangerController.description: Tap changer controller is an equipment controller that controls a tap changer, e.g. how the voltage at the end of a line varies with the load level and compensation of the voltage drop by tap adjustment.

ThyristorControlledSeriesCompensator.description: Thyristor-controlled series capacitors (TCSC) is a type of flexible AC transmission system regulating equipment that is configured with controlled reactors in parallel with sections of a capacitor bank. This combination allows smooth control of the fundamental frequency capacitive reactance over a wide range. The thyristor valve contains a string of series connected high power thyristors. TCSC can control power flows in order to achieve eliminating of line overloads, reducing loop flows and minimising system losses.

ThyristorControlledSeriesCompensator.fle.description: Flexible impedance that can be controlled by the compensator when operating in the capacitive range.  Shall always be positive.
